background: On December 14, 2018, the State of Oregon, the State of Washington, the Nez Perce Tribe, Bonneville Power Administration, Bureau of Reclamation and the Corps entered into the 2019-2021 Spill Operation Agreement, referred to as the flexible spill agreement. The Corps agreed to increase spill to improve juvenile salmonid migration during times of low hydropower demand. For the 2020-2021 spring spill, the flexible spill agreement calls for increasing the total dissolved gas (TDG) cap to 125 percent in the tailraces of dams in the Columbia and Snake rivers. This change to the water quality standard for TDG requires the monitoring of native, resident fishes for incidence of gas bubble trauma (GBT) resulting from increased TDG.The current criteria used to monitor GBT in native, resident nonsalmonids are the ones used by the regional Smolt Monitoring Program to monitor GBT in salmonids. It is unknown whether these criteria are suitable for use in nonsalmonids and how GBT progresses in nonsalmonid species. Therefore, it is necessary to collect resident fish and identify protential GBT.
title: Gas Bubble Trauma for Resident Fish
objectives: Measure the incidence and severity of GBT in Northern Pikeminnow, Smallmouth Bass, and Walleye rearing downstream of Priest Rapids dam during the spring spill period.
Determine feasibility to describe GBT in resident Northern Pikeminnow, Smallmouth Bass, and Walleye fishes while in the field, on a boat, and working at night.
